commit_message:
Stop moving partitions unnecessarily when overload is on.

When overload was on and in use, the ring builder was unnecessarily
moving partitions. It would converge on a good solution and settle
down eventually, but it moved more partitions than necessary along the
way.

There are three partition gatherers used in the ring builder:
dev-removed, dispersion, and weight, in that order. The dev-removed
gatherer will pick up all partitions on removed devices. The
dispersion gatherer picks up replicas of partitions that are
suboptimally dispersed. The weight gatherer picks up partitions on
devices which are overweight.

The weight gatherer was not overload-aware, so it would pick up
partitions that did not need to move. Consider a device that would
normally have 100 partitions assigned, assume we set overload to 0.1
so that this device will hold up to 110 (10 extra) for the sake of
dispersion, and assume the device actually has 104 partitions assigned
to it. The correct behavior is to gather nothing from this device
because it has fewer than the maximum. Prior to this commit, the
weight gatherer would remove 4 partitions from this device; they would
subsequently be reassigned by the overload-aware partition placer
(_reassign_parts()). In a ring with multiple overloaded devices, the
builder would pick up some partitions from each, shuffle them, and
then assign them back to those same devices. Obviously, this just
created extra replication work for no benefit.

Now, the weight gatherer takes overload into account, and will no
longer needlessly gather partitions.

That's not all, though; this change worsened the behavior of a ring
with more overload than necessary. Before, the ring would balance as
best it could, using the minimal amount of overload. With the
weight-gatherer change, the ring builder will stop gathering
partitions once a device reaches its maximum-permissible assignment
including overload.

For example, imagine a 3-replica, 4-zone ring with overload=0.2 and
weights:

  z1: 100
  z2: 60
  z3: 60
  z4: 60

Since z1 has more than 1/3 of the weight, z2, z3, and z4 must take
more than their fair share for the sake of dispersion.

Now, turn up the weights some:

  z1: 100
  z2: 80
  z3: 80
  z4: 80

Overload is no longer needed; this ring can balance. However, z2, z3,
and z4 would end up keeping more than their fair share since (a) they
already had extra due to earlier conditions, and (b) the weight
gatherer won't pick up partitions from them since they're not
overburdened once it takes overload into account.

To fix this, we compute the minimum overload factor required for
optimal dispersion and then use min(user-input-overload,
minimum-overload) during rebalance. This way, we don't overload
devices more than the user says, but if the user sets overload higher
than necessary, we'll still give the best balance possible.

Change-Id: If5666ba654ee25da54f9144f3b78840273a49627

added_lines: def test_unoverload(self): # Start off needing overload to balance, then add capacity until we # don't need overload any more and see that things still balance. # Overload doesn't prevent optimal balancing. rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3, 1) rb.set_overload(0.125) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 2, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.rebalance(seed=12345) # sanity check: our overload is big enough to balance things part_counts = self._partition_counts(rb) self.assertEqual(part_counts[0], 216) self.assertEqual(part_counts[1], 216) self.assertEqual(part_counts[2], 336) # Add some weight: balance improves rb.set_dev_weight(0, 1.5) rb.set_dev_weight(1, 1.5) rb.pretend_min_part_hours_passed() rb.rebalance(seed=12345) part_counts = self._partition_counts(rb) self.assertEqual(part_counts[0], 236) self.assertEqual(part_counts[1], 236) self.assertEqual(part_counts[2], 296) # Even out the weights: balance becomes perfect rb.set_dev_weight(0, 2) rb.set_dev_weight(1, 2) rb.pretend_min_part_hours_passed() rb.rebalance(seed=12345) part_counts = self._partition_counts(rb) self.assertEqual(part_counts[0], 256) self.assertEqual(part_counts[1], 256) self.assertEqual(part_counts[2], 256) # Add some new devices: balance stays optimal rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 2.0 / 3, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdd'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 4, 'region': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 2.0 / 3, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sde'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 5, 'region': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 2.0 / 3, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdf'}) # we're moving more than 1/3 of the replicas but fewer than 2/3, so # we have to do this twice rb.pretend_min_part_hours_passed() rb.rebalance(seed=12345) rb.pretend_min_part_hours_passed() rb.rebalance(seed=12345) part_counts = self._partition_counts(rb) self.assertEqual(part_counts[0], 192) self.assertEqual(part_counts[1], 192) self.assertEqual(part_counts[2], 192) self.assertEqual(part_counts[3], 64) self.assertEqual(part_counts[4], 64) self.assertEqual(part_counts[5], 64) class TestGetRequiredOverload(unittest.TestCase): def assertApproximately(self, a, b, error=1e-6): self.assertTrue(abs(a - b) < error, "%f and %f differ by more than %f" % (a, b, error)) def test_none_needed(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3, 1) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdd'}) # 4 equal-weight devs and 3 replicas: this can be balanced without # resorting to overload at all self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 0) # 3 equal-weight devs and 3 replicas: this can also be balanced rb.remove_dev(3) self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 0) def test_small_zone(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3, 1) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 4, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 4, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 4, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 4, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdd'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 4, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 4, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 5, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 3, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdd'}) # Zone 2 has 7/8 of the capacity of the other two zones, so an # overload of 1/7 will allow things to balance out. self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 1.0 / 7) def test_big_zone(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3, 1) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 4, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 5, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 6, 'region': 0, 'zone': 3, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.3', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 7, 'region': 0, 'zone': 3, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.3', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) # Zone 1 has weight 200, while zones 2, 3, and 4 together have only # 360. The small zones would need to go from 360 to 400 to balance # out zone 1, for an overload of 40/360 = 1/9. self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 1.0 / 9) def test_enormous_zone(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3, 1) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1000, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1000, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 4, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 5, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 6, 'region': 0, 'zone': 3, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 7, 'region': 0, 'zone': 3, 'weight': 60, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) # Zone 1 has weight 2000, while zones 2, 3, and 4 together have only # 360. The small zones would need to go from 360 to 4000 to balance # out zone 1, for an overload of 3640/360. self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 3640.0 / 360) def test_two_big_two_small(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3, 1) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 4, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 45, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 5, 'region': 0, 'zone': 2, 'weight': 45, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 6, 'region': 0, 'zone': 3, 'weight': 35, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 7, 'region': 0, 'zone': 3, 'weight': 35, 'ip': '127.0.0.2', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) # Zones 1 and 2 each have weight 200, while zones 3 and 4 together # have only 160. The small zones would need to go from 160 to 200 to # balance out the big zones, for an overload of 40/160 = 1/4. self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 1.0 / 4) def test_multiple_replicas_each(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 7, 1) rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 100, 'ip': '127.0.0.0', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 70, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 3, 'region': 0, 'zone': 1, 'weight': 70, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) # Zone 0 has more than 4/7 of the weight, so we'll need to bring # zone 1 up to a total of 150 so it can take 3 replicas, so the # overload should be 10/140. self.assertApproximately(rb.get_required_overload(), 10.0 / 140)

commit_message:
Add ring-builder analyzer.

This is a tool to help developers quantify changes to the ring
builder. It takes a scenario (JSON file) describing the builder's
basic parameters (part_power, replicas, etc.) and a number of
"rounds", where each round is a set of operations to perform on the
builder. For each round, the operations are applied, and then the
builder is rebalanced until it reaches a steady state.

The idea is that a developer observes the ring builder behaving
suboptimally, writes a scenario to reproduce the behavior, modifies
the ring builder to fix it, and references the scenario with the
commit so that others can see that things have improved.

I decided to write this after writing my fourth or fifth hacky one-off
script to reproduce some bad behavior in the ring builder.

Change-Id: I114242748368f142304aab90a6d99c1337bced4c

commit_message:
Sort dynamic inventory files in juno

By enabling sort_keys for the files rpc_hostnames_ips.yml and
rpc_inventory.json, both will now be sorted.

Closes-Bug: #1472038

subject: Separate the fetch and validate parts of auth_token
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-12 05:59:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/commit/540e25b0342f92468bff1e9ae6d9f068c416b193', 'message': 'Separate the fetch and validate token processes

Currently when you validate a token if an expiry or bind check fails
then the token will be cached as invalid. This is a particular problem
for a bind check because the next time the token is used the bind might
be valid.

As part of the split of auth_token to make it useful for keystone we
want to separate the logic of what is involved in fetching a token and
how you validate it afterwards.

Move the validation logic after the caching logic. This will mean if a
token is expired the expired data will be stored in the cache - however
in normal operation the expired data will still always be checked for
validity. This removes some tests that check specifically that an
invalid value is cached if a token has expired.

Change-Id: Icbd44f5edbeadb1a52cccf2a481a1e861b0de120
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-17 04:56:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/commit/cde3eed6e5c122fdd45b27efe07bb8e5f4ee5180', 'message': 'Separate the fetch and validate token processes

Currently when you validate a token if an expiry or bind check fails
then the token will be cached as invalid. This is a particular problem
for a bind check because the next time the token is used the bind might
be valid.

As part of the split of auth_token to make it useful for keystone we
want to separate the logic of what is involved in fetching a token and
how you validate it afterwards.

Move the validation logic after the caching logic. This will mean if a
token is expired the expired data will be stored in the cache - however
in normal operation the expired data will still always be checked for
validity. This removes some tests that check specifically that an
invalid value is cached if a token has expired.

Change-Id: Icbd44f5edbeadb1a52cccf2a481a1e861b0de120

Currently when you validate a token if an expiry or bind check fails

commit_message:
Separate the fetch and validate parts of auth_token

Split the validate process into two distinct parts. The fetch process
will retrieve the token data, either from PKI or from the identity
server. It is also responsible for caching this information.

The validate process then looks at the data returned and decides whether
it is allowed for this request. A simplification for later is that token
binding is performed in addition to the validate step because this
really should be performed once per request and not once per token.

Because of this we are no longer caching the validation of a request,
only the actual request data. We therefore remove some tests that were
testing that the validation of a token was cached.

Change-Id: Icbd44f5edbeadb1a52cccf2a481a1e861b0de120
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/40/190940/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not auth_ref: raise exc.InvalidToken(_('Unable to fetch token data ' 'from identity service')) if auth_ref.version == 'v2.0': data = {'access': auth_ref} else: # it's v3. data = {'token': auth_ref} # 0 seconds of validity means is it valid right now. if auth_ref.will_expire_soon(stale_duration=0): raise exc.InvalidToken(_('Token authorization failed')) if _token_is_v2(data) and not auth_ref.project_id: msg = _('Unable to determine service tenancy.') raise exc.InvalidToken(msg) self._confirm_token_bind(auth_ref, request) return auth_ref
deleted_lines: if auth_ref: if auth_ref.version == 'v2.0': data = {'access': auth_ref} else: # it's v3. data = {'token': auth_ref} else: data = None # 0 seconds of validity means is it valid right now. if auth_ref.will_expire_soon(stale_duration=0): raise exc.InvalidToken(_('Token authorization failed')) if _token_is_v2(data) and not auth_ref.project_id: msg = _('Unable to determine service tenancy.') raise exc.InvalidToken(msg) self._confirm_token_bind(auth_ref, request) if not cached: return auth_ref

commit_message:
add domain_remap to /info

Also added the value of default_reseller_prefix to /info. I did not
add the reseller_prefixes value to /info because deployers may not
want to expose all of the resellers that are available.

Change-Id: I9ca2f002dc395913bb646390d6908dfb8f554df1

commit_message:
Simplify fernet rotation code

The fernet rotation code contained a complicated calculation for
what files were to be removed.

Also, stopped modifying a config option. Config is read-only.

Change-Id: Ib21f98623fa1aa1624f06b4227e1e8448f62b5e3

commit_message:
Tests for correct key removed

The tests didn't verify that the correct key is removed when
the keys are rotated.

Also, other cleanups

- Removed use of six where range is fine.
- Fixed order of arguments to assertEqual

Change-Id: I9accc27eb982943032acc8b4364c88c8bc8fe6b7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/88/194388/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def keys(self): """Key files converted to numbers.""" return sorted( int(x) for x in os.listdir(CONF.fernet_tokens.key_repository)) @property return len(self.keys) for max_active_keys in range(min_active_keys, 52 + 1): exp_keys = [0, 1] key_no = 2 # keep track of next key self.assertEqual(exp_keys, self.keys) for rotation in range(max_active_keys - min_active_keys): self.assertEqual(rotation + 3, self.key_repository_size) exp_keys.append(key_no) key_no += 1 self.assertEqual(exp_keys, self.keys) self.assertEqual(self.key_repository_size, max_active_keys) for rotation in range(10): self.assertEqual(max_active_keys, self.key_repository_size) exp_keys.pop(1) exp_keys.append(key_no) key_no += 1 self.assertEqual(exp_keys, self.keys)
deleted_lines: import six return len(os.listdir(CONF.fernet_tokens.key_repository)) for max_active_keys in six.moves.range(min_active_keys, 52 + 1): self.assertEqual(min_active_keys, self.key_repository_size) for rotation in six.moves.range(max_active_keys - min_active_keys): self.assertEqual(max_active_keys, self.key_repository_size) for rotation in six.moves.range(10): self.assertEqual(self.key_repository_size, max_active_keys)

commit_message:
Add wording to error message in TestObjectVersions.test_relationships

Commit eafe8ae066f14a6b3e562a5a25edb20e617fbee2 fixed the
test_relationships method to be more accurate for object list
relationships.

However, the existing error message is a bit misleading now if your
parent/child object versions are correct in the code but you forgot to
update the child version in the object_relationships map used in the
test.

This change adds a reminder of something to check when this test fails.

Change-Id: I199b999520e3d67dd42f3d561f668c334e1b4d0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/197684/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'the child object. Also remember to update versions ' 'of child objects as necessary in the ' 'object_relationships mapping used in this test.')

commit_message:
acceptance: checkout stable/kilo puppet modules

When pulling the modules using the Puppetfile provided by puppet-openstack-integration,
we need to make sure to pull stable/kilo.

Change-Id: Ibde9ab03019978a812ee24259f36b47302e5735e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat refs/changes/50/200350/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: on host, "git clone -b stable/kilo https://git.openstack.org/#{repo} #{repo}"

commit_message:
Fix project requirements check to work with "extras"

Process "extras" defined in a project setup.cfg properly by looping over
the dictionary's member items and not the dictionary itself.

Do not compare comments associated with requirements, since those are
always collected as a set of unnamed requirements and many of the
comments from global-requirements.txt are not needed in the local
project file (especially when the dependencies for which the comments
are relevant are not used).

Change-Id: I78838dcd4da43b3c1d2610ac87a3ec55b9535646
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/47/200647/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for name, content in project.extras(self.project).items(): if not name: # Comments show up as unnamed requirements. There's no # point in copying comments related to packages that # aren't in the destination, so ignore the comments # entirely. continue

Specs for email alarm notification

Implements blueprint EmailAlarmNotifier

Change-Id: I0ff5e62ccc651ca7d135b6aa20d325b7fb9e4ce6

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== EmailAlarmNotifier for ceilometer-alarm-notifier service ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/emailalarmnotifier-for-ceilometer-alarm-notifier Problem description =================== Ceilometer currently has only log and rest notifier. If cloud operator and/or End User want to now about configured alarm details over email, right now there are no options. this blueprint will add another option to notify alarm over email. Proposed change =============== email notifier can be configure while creating alarm. ceilometer CLI for 'alarm-threshold-create' can specify --alarm-action as 'email://' Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The end user should be able to interact via the existing API and CLI. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- This change should not have any major impact on performance/Scalability. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: * yatinkumbhare-c Other contributors: None Ongoing maintainer: * yatinkumbhare-c Work Items ---------- * Add entry point and implementation for email notification. * Add Unit/Integration test coverage Future lifecycle ================ ongoing maintenance will be handled by the Ceilometer team, myself included. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and integration Tests will be added to cover the necessary. Documentation Impact ==================== Docs needs to be updated to add email notification action. References ========== None

commit_message:
Remove usage of assert_called_once in mocks

This was never a real part of the mock api, but mock was happily mocking
it out and letting the tests pass. The new mock release made this
behaviour break, causing tests to fail on all patches. This patch
replaces instances of assert_called_once with an assert of the mock's
call_count.

Change-Id: I41ea0456acda86147ce3a7da0311e926782b4542
Closes-Bug: #1473369

commit_message:
Viewing of CADF audit events from Ceilometer DB

In OpenStack, to comply with security standards, it was necessary to
audit the operations performed by a cloud administrator or a tenant user
on OpenStack components.
OpenStack Icehouse release, in the form of the blueprint explained at
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Ceilometer/blueprints/
support-standard-audit-formats
has introduced WSGI middleware "Audit Filter" for each project to listen to
incoming API requests and generate audit notifications in the Cloud Auditing
Data Federation (CADF) format. These audit notifications are eventually
transported using an audit notifier over the Notification Bus.
Audit Event Listener collects these notifications from the Notification Bus
and forwards them as events on the Event Bus to which the Ceilometer
Collector is registered.
The Ceilometer Collector stores these CADF events in a Data Store
like MongoDB.
Although this information is stored in the Ceilometer datastore, there is
no way currently for Ceilometer to either view, or filter this data either
in Horizon UI or Ceilometer CLIs.

The current blueprint proposes to enhance the Horizon UI and Ceilometer CLI
to view and filter CADF events.

Change-Id: Idb0afe576699045e5c55e85690f15615681feaa9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/98/110898/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================================== Enhancing Ceilometer Horizon and CLI for CADF audit entries =========================================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/viewing-cadf-audit-events Problem description =================== In OpenStack, to comply with security standards, it was necessary to audit the operations performed by a cloud administrator or a tenant user on OpenStack components. OpenStack Icehouse release, in the form of the blueprint explained at https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Ceilometer/blueprints/ support-standard-audit-formats has introduced WSGI middleware "Audit Filter" for each project to listen to incoming API requests and generate audit notifications in the Cloud Auditing Data Federation (CADF) format. These audit notifications are eventually transported using an audit notifier over the Notification Bus. Audit Event Listener collects these notifications from the Notification Bus and forwards them as events on the Event Bus to which the Ceilometer Collector is registered. The Ceilometer Collector stores these CADF events in a Data Store like MongoDB. Although this information is stored in the Ceilometer datastore, there is no way currently for Ceilometer to either view, or filter this data either in Horizon UI or Ceilometer CLIs. Proposed change =============== The current blueprint proposes to enhance the Horizon UI and Ceilometer CLI to support the following use cases. Horizon dashboard use cases: 1. As an administrator, I should be able to click on "AuditLogs" link in the left hand pane to view all the CADF audit events from the Ceilometer database. To support this use case, "AuditLogs" link will be introduced in the left hand side panel. On the right hand side, by default, all the audit events will be displayed. 2. As an administrator, I should be able to view details of a specific audit event which is uniquely identified by its ID. To support this, the user can click on the Audit ID value on the right hand side pane and it will take the user to a screen which displays the details of the audit event. 3. As an administrator, I should be able to filter audit log events based on date-time range, Target Name, Project ID, Project Name, User ID, User Name, Role, Event Action, Resource Type, Resource ID and Outcome. Ceilometer CLI use cases: Listing all the audit log events ceilometer auditlog-list Show a particular audit event by specifying its ID ceilometer auditlog-show -a 53a116dd31161905d0d8f29c Filtering the audit logs based on date time range ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'start=2014-06-18;end=2014-06-19' Filtering the audit logs based on event_action ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'event_action=delete' Filtering the audit logs based on outcome ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'outcome=success' Filtering the audit logs based on project ID ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'project_id=27f36508a3e1417facfac0d0809a1740' Filtering the audit logs based on the project name ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'project_name=admin' Filtering the audit logs based on the resource ID ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'resource_id=fc978c2c-87a3-46cf-b53c-36409eed3ccb' Filtering the audit logs based on the resource type ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'resource_type=ports' Filtering the audit logs based on the user ID ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'user_id=8fa01f47b17447a89c426cc12252bed8' Filtering the audit logs based on the user name ceilometer auditlog-list -q 'user_name=admin' Alternatives ------------ A user has to develop a separate application to read and filter on the data stored in the Ceilometer Database (MongoDB), which is quite cumbersome. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Auditlog resource noun will be provided with READ REST interface. Attributes of the resource are defined in the below table. +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Description | |Name | | | | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |audit_id |string |RO, admin| Unique iddentifier of the event | | | | | | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |outcome |string |RO, admin| outcome of the operation | | | | | | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |user_id |string |RO, admin| ID of the user who performed | | | | | the operation | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |event_time |string |RO, admin| Time at which the operation was | | | | | performed | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |target_name |string |RO, admin| OpenStack component on which | | | | | the operation was performed | | | | | like neutron/nova/etc. | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |resource_id |string |RO, admin| ID of the resource on which | | | | | the operation was performed | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |project_name |string |RO, admin| name of the project on which | | | | | the operation was performed | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |role |string |RO, admin| role of the user who performed | | | | | the operation | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |cadf |string |RO, admin| CADF event | | | | | | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |event_action |string |RO, admin| action performed on a resource | | | | | | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |project_id |string |RO, admin| ID of the project | | | | | | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |user_name |string |RO, admin| name of the user who performed | | | | | the operation | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ |resource_type |string |RO, admin| type of resource like port, | | | | | network, etc. | +--------------+-------+---------+---------------------------------+ 1. List all audit logs This operation does not require a request body. JSON Request GET /v2/auditlogs HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/json JSON Response : { "outcome": "pending", "user_id": "8fa01f47b17447a89c426cc12252bed8", "event_time": "2014-06-18 04:34:37", "audit_id": "53a116dd31161905d0d8f29c", "target_name": "neutron", "resource_id": " ", "project_name": "admin", "role": "_member_,admin", "cadf": "{ u'typeURI': u'http://schemas.dmtf.org/cloud/audit/1.0/event', u'eventTime': u'2014-06-18T04:34:37.888091+0000', u'target': { u'typeURI': u'service/network', u'addresses': [{u'url': u'http://100.30.30.115:9696/', u'name': u'admin'}, {u'url': u'http://100.30.30.115:9696/', u'name': u'private'}, {u'url': u'http://15.212.181.132:9696/', u'name': u'public'}], u'name': u'neutron', u'id': u'openstack:485c5f78c2f8474299f79698a9df81a2'}, u'observer': {u'id': u'target'}, u'tags': [u'correlation_id?value=openstack:04e86f31-84b2-4fa9-80ca-bbcfc2dc416f'], u'eventType': u'activity', u'initiator': { u'typeURI': u'service/security/account/user', u'name': u'admin', u'credential': {u'token': u'e9c2 xxxxxxxx db42', u'identity_status': u'Confirmed' }, u'host': { u'agent': u'python-neutronclient', u'address': u'15.212.181.132'}, u'project_id': u'openstack:27f36508a3e1417facfac0d0809a1740', u'id': u'openstack:8fa01f47b17447a89c426cc12252bed8' }, u'action': u'read', u'outcome': u'pending', u'id': u'openstack:d944c8ff-47ad-4bed-a8a4-43289c7976eb', u'requestPath': u'/v2.0/networks.json?fields=id&name=net-1' }", "event_action": "read", "project_id": "27f36508a3e1417facfac0d0809a1740", "user_name": "admin", "resource_type": "networks" } Normal Response Code(s): OK (200) Error Response Code(s): internal error (500) 2. Show auditlog with a specified audit ID This operation does not require a request body. JSON Request GET /v2/auditlogs/{audit_id} HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/json JSON Response : { "outcome": "pending", "user_id": "8fa01f47b17447a89c426cc12252bed8", "event_time": "2014-06-18 04:34:37", "audit_id": "53a116dd31161905d0d8f29c", "target_name": "neutron", "resource_id": " ", "project_name": "admin", "role": "_member_,admin", "cadf": "{ u'typeURI': u'http://schemas.dmtf.org/cloud/audit/1.0/event', u'eventTime': u'2014-06-18T04:34:37.888091+0000', u'target': {u'typeURI': u'service/network', u'addresses': [{u'url': u'http://100.30.30.115:9696/', u'name': u'admin'}, {u'url': u'http://100.30.30.115:9696/', u'name': u'private'}, {u'url': u'http://15.212.181.132:9696/', u'name': u'public'}], u'name': u'neutron', u'id': u'openstack:485c5f78c2f8474299f79698a9df81a2'}, u'observer': {u'id': u'target'}, u'tags': [u'correlation_id?value=openstack:04e86f31-84b2-4fa9-80ca-bbcfc2dc416f'], u'eventType': u'activity', u'initiator': {u'typeURI': u'service/security/account/user', u'name': u'admin', u'credential': {u'token': u'e9c2 xxxxxxxx db42', u'identity_status': u'Confirmed'}, u'host': {u'agent': u'python-neutronclient', u'address': u'15.212.181.132'}, u'project_id': u'openstack:27f36508a3e1417facfac0d0809a1740', u'id': u'openstack:8fa01f47b17447a89c426cc12252bed8'}, u'action': u'read', u'outcome': u'pending', u'id': u'openstack:d944c8ff-47ad-4bed-a8a4-43289c7976eb', u'requestPath': u'/v2.0/networks.json?fields=id&name=net-1'}", "event_action": "read", "project_id": "27f36508a3e1417facfac0d0809a1740", "user_name": "admin", "resource_type": "networks" } Normal Response Code(s): OK (200) Error Response Code(s): internal error (500) 3. List audit logs within specified date time range This operation does not require a request body. JSON Request GET /v2/auditlogs?q.field=start&q.field=end&q.op=eq&q.op=eq&q.value=2014-06-18&q.value=2014-06-19 HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/json JSON Response : [ { "outcome": "pending", "user_id": Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Current status: POC code ready. Will be submitted for review soon. Assignee(s) ----------- Maruti Kamat (marutik) Work Items ---------- Implementation predominantly is CLI and Horizon centric. Highlevel tasks include : - Introduce a new resource noun (say, auditlogs) in the Ceilometer READ REST call interface will be exposed for this noun. This REST call will be used by the clients (CLI and Horizon dashboard). The component that will be modified is Ceilometer server. - Ceilometer CLI Ceilometer client will be upgraded to support the new audit logs options to view and filter audit events. The component that will be modified is Ceilometer client. - Horizon dashboard for Ceilometer Horizon dashboard client will be upgraded to support audit logs view and provide filter options. The component that will be modified is Horizon. Future work: - Provide more filters in Ceilometer CLI and Horizon dashboard Dependencies ============ Ceilometer Horizon dashboard Ceilometer CLI Documentation Testing ======= Testing will be done with Ceilometer CLIs and Horizon dashboard after enabling CADF middleware and audit notification driver. Documentation Impact ==================== Current documentation will have to be enhanced to add the content specific to CLI and Horizon changes in Ceilometer References ========== https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6wARyYJHf0ZZ1lpRnVra1k2c2M/edit?usp=sharing

subject: VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-26 20:54:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/cbfa3022691cf8b770742f4f5e8f4383e1ed2836', 'message': "VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests

As part of the work to allow VPN functionals job to run when Neutron
commits are reviewed, we need to be more intelligent about how
dependencies are resolved in the tox.ini for this repo.

This commit does the same as LBaaS, using a script to determine whether
an existing Neutron repo exists (and use that for a Neutron patch-set
running the VPN tests) or whether the Neutron repo needs to be cloned
(for a VPN patch set).

This must be upstreamed, before allowing the VPN functional job to run
for Neutron jobs.

Change-Id: Idb3c4dff0dbb40e30b2b49591df0b014b769f167
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-26 23:29:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/a7ea8ddc3eb0859930f4054f41a463781278fbc0', 'message': "VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests

As part of the work to allow VPN functionals job to run when Neutron
commits are reviewed, we need to be more intelligent about how
dependencies are resolved in the tox.ini for this repo.

This commit does the same as LBaaS, using a script to determine whether
an existing Neutron repo exists (and use that for a Neutron patch-set
running the VPN tests) or whether the Neutron repo needs to be cloned
(for a VPN patch set).

This must be upstreamed, before allowing the VPN functional job to run
for Neutron jobs.

Change-Id: Idb3c4dff0dbb40e30b2b49591df0b014b769f167
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-06-29 21:47:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/b17c050f3c0a5faf84f63d2a38562990e25b333e', 'message': "VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests

As part of the work to allow VPN functionals job to run when Neutron
commits are reviewed, we need to be more intelligent about how
dependencies are resolved in the tox.ini for this repo.

This commit does the same as LBaaS, using a script to determine whether
an existing Neutron repo exists (and use that for a Neutron patch-set
running the VPN tests) or whether the Neutron repo needs to be cloned
(for a VPN patch set).

In addition, since VPN needs to run rootwrap_deploy.sh, it is cloned
to this repo, so that there is not a dependency on neutron scripts.

This must be upstreamed, before allowing the VPN functional job to run
for Neutron jobs.

Change-Id: Idb3c4dff0dbb40e30b2b49591df0b014b769f167
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-07-01 15:17:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/31ad77bebe8722695882d3237d887d9fe6c39675', 'message': "VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests

As part of the work to allow VPN functionals job to run when Neutron
commits are reviewed, we need to be more intelligent about how
dependencies are resolved in the tox.ini for this repo.

This commit does the same as LBaaS, using a script to determine whether
an existing Neutron repo exists (and use that for a Neutron patch-set
running the VPN tests) or whether the Neutron repo needs to be cloned
(for a VPN patch set).

With the VPN repo, the rootwrap config file and filters need to be set
up. A new script is introduced to perform the needed actions (similar
to some of what rootwrap_deploy.sh does for neutron).

To remove a dependency on Neutron, the functional-testing.filters is
copied to the repo as well.

NOTE: To run functional tests locally, one needs to set VENV for the
desired functional target and invoke configure_vpn_for_func_testing.sh.
Next, run tox for the functional target with --notest to setup the
virtual environment. Then, install Neutron into the virtual env. Finally,
the functional test can then be invoked.

This must be upstreamed, before allowing the VPN functional job to run
for Neutron jobs.

Change-Id: Idb3c4dff0dbb40e30b2b49591df0b014b769f167
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-07-01 22:37:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/208214f3fed8f78b183c280bb5fb3c2bec69068a', 'message': "VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests

As part of the work to allow VPN functionals job to run when Neutron
commits are reviewed, we need to be more intelligent about how
dependencies are resolved in the tox.ini for this repo.

This commit does the same as LBaaS, using a script to determine whether
an existing Neutron repo exists (and use that for a Neutron patch-set
running the VPN tests) or whether the Neutron repo needs to be cloned
(for a VPN patch set).

With the VPN repo, the rootwrap config file and filters need to be set
up. A new script is introduced to perform the needed actions (similar
to some of what rootwrap_deploy.sh does for neutron).

To remove a dependency on Neutron, the functional-testing.filters is
copied to the repo as well.

NOTE: To run functional tests locally, one needs to set VENV for the
desired functional target and invoke configure_vpn_for_func_testing.sh.
Next, run tox for the functional target with --notest to setup the
virtual environment. Then, install Neutron into the virtual env. Finally,
the functional test can then be invoked.

This must be upstreamed, before allowing the VPN functional job to run
for Neutron jobs.

Change-Id: Idb3c4dff0dbb40e30b2b49591df0b014b769f167

commit_message:
VPNaaS: Don't clone neutron automatically for tests

As part of the work to allow VPN functionals job to run when Neutron
commits are reviewed, we need to be more intelligent about how
dependencies are resolved in the tox.ini for this repo.

This commit does the same as LBaaS, using a script to determine whether
an existing Neutron repo exists (and use that for a Neutron patch-set
running the VPN tests) or whether the Neutron repo needs to be cloned
(for a VPN patch set).

With the VPN repo, the rootwrap config file and filters need to be set
up. The deploy_rootwrap script is modified to do all actions related to
setup, instead of doing part of that in tox.ini, as before. In addition,
rootwrap config and needed filters for testing from Neutron are added to
this repo, so there is no dependency on Neutron (whose location cannot
be assumed in the gate).

NOTE: To run functional tests locally, one needs to set VENV for the
desired functional target and invoke configure_vpn_for_func_testing.sh.
Next, run tox for the functional target with --notest to setup the
virtual environment. Then, install Neutron into the virtual env. Finally,
the functional test can then be invoked.

This must be upstreamed, before allowing the VPN functional job to run
for Neutron jobs.

Change-Id: Idb3c4dff0dbb40e30b2b49591df0b014b769f167
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/37/196237/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = {toxinidir}/tools/tox_install.sh {opts} {packages} deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-29 07:12:09.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/alarms-gnocchi-integration.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs/commit/a1ae06c05f7cec266fafe176cd29cf4554cc666a', 'message': 'Alarms making use of Gnocchi

commit_message:
Alarms making use of Gnocchi

Change-Id: Ie1d34e3d30e0b51085bbfc9a4b4ffcd1664e5d84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/81/109581/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Alarm evaluation making use of TSDBaaS (Gnocchi) ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/alarms-gnocchi-integration Problem description =================== Each time a point in time is reached when an alarm needs to be evaluated, the following process takes place: 1. filter samples by desired time interval 2. sift through those samples finding the ones that match the query 3. calculate the desired statistic 4. compare with threshold Come Gnocchi, this process would probably be changed a bit behind the scenes into: 1. find entities that match the query 2. merge the entities somehow, which requires potentially complex logic in Gnocchi, either: a) altering entities to add an archive with the alarm evaluator's desired granularity (breaks the data ownership principle, since alarm evaluator does not own the entities) b) tagging entities (still requires a search through the tags at each evaluation) c) ... 3. compare with threshold Proposed change =============== *TL;DR*: This approach moves the processing and filtering to when the samples are ingested instead of when the alarm is evaluated and thus enables the alarms to be evaluated in near real-time AND provides wide-dimension alarming compatible with Gnocchi. Let's leverage the TSDBaaS (Gnocchi) and have a separate entity for each alarm. Each such entity would contain all the data points relevant to its alarm and would have an archive that would be set up according to the evaluation interval, alarm period and aggregation method. This simplifies the aforementioned process to: 1. read the latest <evaluation_periods> values from the entity's archive 2. compare them with threshold Also, statistics for one period are calculated only once, whereas currently,if a period falls within multiple evaluations, its statistics are recalculated every time. .. You can skip the analogy if you want, it's not really necessary :-) Cocktail analogy: you have a list of cocktails you need to prepare for a party and each cocktail has a list of ingredients that you need to mix. You go to the store and:: for each cocktail: for each ingredient: find it in the store put it into basket mix the ingredients With the proposed approach, the store does you a favor and prepares baskets for each of your cocktails in advance. They fill your baskets with the correct ingredients on the fly as they get them from distributors. When they see you come in, they mix the ingredients into cocktails. All you need to do is take the drinks home! you = alarm evaluator the store = storage/gnocchi ingredients = samples cocktail = calculated statistic for an alarm *IMPLEMENTATION DETAILS* This change would be implemented with two new components. * *Alarm Publisher* A new Ceilometer pipeline publisher, which publishes the samples to Alarm Distributor. To make the setup easy to scale horizontally, we could push these samples to an AMQP queue, where they can be picked up by one or more Alarm Distributors (using oslo.messaging). * *Alarm Distributor* Maintains a decision tree that tells which samples should be pushed to which entities (meaning that the sample is relevant to one or more alarms). It builds its decision tree out of the alarms' rule queries. (It would query the alarms periodically or could even receive notifications about CRUD alarm operations from the API layer). When a sample arrives, the distributor walks through the decision tree and gets a list of the alarms (their entities, rather) this sample is relevant to. It then pushes a new datapoint into those entities. The decision tree is a multi-level map. The levels are as follows (TBD): 1. meter_name 2. project_id 3. resource_id 4. remaining query parameters The values stored are sets of entities for the sample to be pushed to. This would allow us very fast dispatch of relevant sample volumes to their respective alarm entities. This approach is feasible with the current state of metadata but would be even more performant if the metadata was more constrained. :: +----------------------+ | | | Ceilometer | | pipeline | | / \ | +--------v-+-v---------+ | | | | RPC | Alarm | |publisher | publisher | | | (new) | +-----+----+------+----+ RPC | | v +-----------+ RPC (horizontally scalable) +----------+ | |Collector | v |----------| +----------------+ +---------------+ |Gnocchi | | | | | |Dispatcher| |AlarmDistributor| |Alarm Evaluator| +-----+----+ | (new) | | | | +------+---------+ +---------------+ REST | /|\ REST ^ v *GNOCCHI* v v v | REST +------------------------------------------------+--------+ | | | cpu_util_entity, ... , alarm1_entity, alarm2_entity, ...| | | +---------------------------------------------------------+ *Alarm Evaluator* would use the existing code, but the threshold evaluator would be simplified to only read the relevant values from the alarm's entity. Alternatives ------------ TODO Data model impact ----------------- TODO REST API impact --------------- No changes are necessary to the alarm API. Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- TODO Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- TODO Other deployer impact --------------------- TODO Developer impact ---------------- TODO Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: nejc-saje Ongoing maintainer: nejc-saje Work Items ---------- TODO Future lifecycle ================ TODO Dependencies ============ * Gnocchi Testing ======= TODO Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

Change-Id: I19863ac67472b3b1e511118f3041abe4ee862aa4

commit_message:
Add resource metadata updater transformer

Change-Id: I19863ac67472b3b1e511118f3041abe4ee862aa4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/84/153984/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= Add resource metadata updater transformer ========================================= TODO: register a bp on launchpad after the bp name is settled https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/example Problem description =================== We have a user case that wants to get resources/meters/samples which come from Nova, Cinder, Glance, Heat and etc seperately, but we cannot do such thing by using current feature. The source of samples are set to the sample_source configure option which by default is openstack, so we cannot tell each resource by the source. The only way we can do is building a map according to measurements document or source code directly, then consider user defined pipeline.yaml on target system, then filter each meter and get the final result. The map can be unpredicatable if the pipeline.yaml has defined new metrics by using rate_of_change or there are vendor related new metrics on target system. In large scale, list all resources/meters/samples of a project will have performance issue and cause waste of bandwidth (especially for admin user queries without project filter). Proposed change =============== We can add a new transformer, which updates some metadata keys to a kind of samples, for example, append a `belong` key with service name `nova` to metric `cpu`, then resource will have it in metadata too, finally, we can request resources/meters by command like this:: ceilometer resource-list -q metadata.belong=nova ceilometer meter-list -q metadata.belong=nova ceilometer sample-list -q metadata.belong=nova the result will only contain resources, metrics or samples belong to Nova service. Alternatives ------------ The proposed change is to updates sample's metadata by what ever user defined, it is very broad, maybe we should limit to that can only append non-existent fields. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- User can filter resources, metrics or samples by new metadata appended by pipeline. Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- New transformer is added, cloud operator can specify new transformer to enable this feature. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- If cloud operator use this feature, new metadata fields will be added, so database burden will be increased correspondingly. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ZhiQiang Fan <aji-zqfan> Other contributors: None Ongoing maintainer: ZhiQiang Fan <aji-zqfan> Work Items ---------- Add a new transformer which can update sample's resource_metadata. Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Will include unit test code. Documentation Impact ==================== Will need to update ceilometer configuration document. References ========== None

commit_message:
N1Kv:Adding params for IPv6 communication with VSM

Adding ability to configure IPv6 control address of VSM,
in the n1kv.conf file, to enable N1kv VEM to talk to VSM
over IPv6

Change-Id: Iac92569ec19a879091111f78474aebb83292999d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/81/198181/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TAG: l3control-ipv6addr # Description: IPv6 Address of VSM Mgmt I/F # Optional: No # Default: ::1 # restart_on_modify: No l3control-ipv6addr <%= @n1kv_vsm_ipv6 %> <% if @n1kv_vsm_ipv6 != '::1' -%> svs-mode V6 <% end -%>

commit_message:
Complete qpid support

The puppet-trove module only had partial, non-working qpid support
until now. The qpid_* parameters were documented and included in
some manifests, but not in init.pp, and rpc_backend was never set
in the config files, so Trove would always use RabbitMQ.

The fix also includes moving qpid parameters from the DEFAULT
section to oslo_messaging_qpid in the config files, to avoid
deprecation warnings in Kilo and later releases.

Change-Id: I12853f843f40e2312e7fe3bb81739be743641583
Closes-bug: #1468312
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-trove refs/changes/41/195041/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: context 'when using qpid' do let :pre_condition do "class { 'trove': nova_proxy_admin_pass => 'verysecrete', rpc_backend => 'trove.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid', qpid_hostname => '10.0.0.1', qpid_username => 'guest', qpid_password => 'password'}" end it 'configures trove-taskmanager with qpid' do is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('DEFAULT/rpc_backend').with_value('trove.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_hostname').with_value('10.0.0.1') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_username').with_value('guest') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_password').with_value('password') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_protocol').with_value('tcp') end end context 'when using qpid with SSL enabled' do let :pre_condition do "class { 'trove': nova_proxy_admin_pass => 'verysecrete', rpc_backend => 'trove.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid', qpid_hostname => '10.0.0.1', qpid_username => 'guest', qpid_password => 'password', qpid_protocol => 'ssl'}" end it 'configures trove-taskmanager with qpid' do is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('DEFAULT/rpc_backend').with_value('trove.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_hostname').with_value('10.0.0.1') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_username').with_value('guest') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_password').with_value('password') is_expected.to contain_trove_taskmanager_config('oslo_messaging_qpid/qpid_protocol').with_value('ssl') end end

commit_message:
Refactor quota limit summary template

Refactor the quota limit summary template to allow easier customisation.
Also change it so that it removes the 'of' when there is no quota limits in
place so that it just reads Used 'x' (No Limit).

Added tests for checking usage['charts'] is in the context and that (No Limit)
is present when there is an infinite quota on the page.

Change-Id: Iba62ca89e53f0d6b9c583e4cc450e853c18ba107
Closes-bug: 1439717
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/47/170147/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return _("(No Limit)") return '-1'

commit_message:
Add basic SSL for master node UI

Set port 8443 listening for SSL connections using standard
localhost key and certificate generated during openssl installation.

Remove SSLv3 from protocols and RC4 from ciphers.

Implements-blueprint: ssl-endpoints
Change-Id: I1cd44930d648df00070151f6dc825b7cbd387858

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-10 16:01:26.000000000', 'files': ['nova/service.py', 'requirements.txt', 'nova/tests/unit/fake_notifier.py', 'etc/nova/api-paste.ini', 'nova/test.py', 'nova/rpc.py', 'nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e558996a54412c528a4023d509678651c95e2609', 'message': "Integrate OSprofiler and Nova

This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows
secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and add first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

Set's olso.messaging notifer instance (to send notifications to Ceilometer)

*) Fix fake notifier

Based on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105096/

Change-Id: I2fa76cc6c9e637d30402d0f2ab41de7a039718ff
Co-Authored-By: Boris Pavlovic <boris@pavlovic.me>
Signed-off-by: Munoz, Obed N <obed.n.munoz@intel.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Integrate OSprofiler and Nova

*) Add osprofiler wsgi middleware
This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows
secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and add first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

*) Add initialization of osprofiler at start of serivce
Set's olso.messaging notifer instance (to send notifications to Ceilometer)

*) Fix fake notifier

Based on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105096/

Change-Id: I2fa76cc6c9e637d30402d0f2ab41de7a039718ff
Co-Authored-By: Boris Pavlovic <boris@pavlovic.me>
Signed-off-by: Munoz, Obed N <obed.n.munoz@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/05/200605/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osprofiler.sqlalchemy import sqlalchemyCONF.import_group("profiler", "nova.service") if CONF.profiler.enabled and CONF.profiler.trace_sqlalchemy: osprofiler.sqlalchemy.add_tracing(sqlalchemy, _ENGINE_FACADE[facade].get_engine(), "db")

commit_message:
Add test showing password logged

There was no test that showed that the password is logged when a
user is created or admin changes user password.

Change-Id: I5ffa04e9ac359355cff47a622731f1bf6a27ea7b
Partial-Bug: #1465922
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/03/193703/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import loggingimport fixtures def test_create_user_password_not_logged(self): # When a user is created, the password isn't logged at any level. # FIXME(blk-u): This doesn't work as expected, see bug 1465922 log_fix = self.useFixture(fixtures.FakeLogger(level=logging.DEBUG)) ref = self.new_user_ref(domain_id=self.domain_id) self.post( '/users', body={'user': ref}) # This should be assert*Not*In, see bug 1465922 self.assertIn(ref['password'], log_fix.output)

commit_message:
Implement Advanced Firewalling support

* Provide a Define function which will allow to manage IPtables rules.
* Manage rules in 'pre' and 'post' Puppet stages, it allows to create
  rules before and after regular Puppet stages (ie: to make sure no rule
  exists *before* and everything is blocked *after* regular Puppet
  stages)

Change-Id: I84fc79096f6fc3db76a61d012d8cb62dd12bdd89

commit_message:
Pin mock for python 2.6

We still need to support python 2.6 in several places, but the mock
library release 1.1.0 no longer supports it. So, pin the version of mock
we use when testing under python 2.6.

Change-Id: I0cfab6d13e5d9e744cb302c86a2c21269923e75d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/83/200583/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mock>=1.0;python_version!="2.6" mock==1.0.1;python_version=="2.6"

commit_message:
acceptance: checkout stable/kilo puppet modules

When pulling the modules using the Puppetfile provided by puppet-openstack-integration,
we need to make sure to pull stable/kilo.

Change-Id: I91976f32eb39540b4bab7559268575ae92ed33aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/13/200213/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix failures related to the mock 1.1.0 release

The functional gate is also failing due to a recent
change introduced in devstack -> I613f1bdc6673f0c4bfe29aaab7b514348a617a8c

This fixes both the gates, functional and unit tests.

Co-Authored-By: Thomas Herve <therve@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1473398
Change-Id: Ia77a1fd884c6346edfb90777e91a51d279ccd92a

commit_message:
Added valid values of operator to response body

when an event query is requested with invalid operator as query parameter,
the response will contain valid list of operator as suggestion.

Closes-Bug: #1407378

Change-Id: I82ed0b8b61ed5bf297efe890cee10000f5ffb7a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/35/196535/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: error = (_(("operator {} is not supported. the supported data type is: %(supported)s") % {'type': type, 'supported': base.operation_kind}).format(i.op))

commit_message:
Adding Angular Identity Projects Panel

This patch adds a blank Projects panel to the Identity dashboard.
Table, forms and actions will be added in subsequent patches.

Change-Id: Id940ec62ad6f956e4884d194c672a0131d22e0d6
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-projects
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/25/191225/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Allow IPAM backend switch
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-05 14:12:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ca22eb689900fa37826817f2916c6a842e7928b8', 'message': 'Refactor db_base_plugin_v2.py to use new IPAM

* WIP *
It is early version of refactored db_base_plugin, so
- it is ugly;
- it does not work;
- major part of functionality is not yet implemented;
But you still can review approach if you want.

Changing db_base_plugin_v2.py to use new IPAM interface for ip
allocation.
During development cycle ipam functionality will be available only after
turning on use_pluggable_ipam config variable.

turning on use_pluggable_ipam config variable.

Additionally contains fix for passing context down to ipam driver.

"}, {'number': 25, 'created': '2015-03-23 12:52:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/fa08f93e8dd32a0849647d2714d07112c40b9eb9', 'message': "Refactor db_base_plugin_v2.py to use new IPAM

Rebased on Reference IPAM driver and enabled pluggable_ipam
to execute all tests in CI using new IPAM.
Most likely will cause a lot of tests to fail, but will help to
identify missed parts.

Additionally contains fix for passing context down to ipam driver.
It's a heavy debugging version unless all UT got fixed.
Several not good assumptions so far:
- if context is passed to driver, singleton logic can not be used;
- reference driver code(any driver) should not create new transaction
  inside(i.e. assume it is in already running transaction) to have
  ability to do rollback actions on db_base level, because rollback
  action (deallocate for allocate) should be called before database
  rollback happened

Added methods for using new IPAM interface instead of old backed-in
version of IPAM.
Added new config variable 'use_pluggable_ipam' for switching between new
and old IPAM implementation.
By default new IPAM is turned off.

DocImpact
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I81806a43ecc6f0a7b293ce3e70d09d1e266b9f02

It's a heavy debugging version unless all UT got fixed.
Several not good assumptions so far:
- reference driver code(any driver) should not create new transaction
  inside(i.e. assume it is in already running transaction) to have
  ability to do rollback actions on db_base level, because rollback
  action (deallocate for allocate) should be called before database
  rollback happened

Added methods for using new IPAM interface instead of old backed-in
version of IPAM.
Added new config variable 'use_pluggable_ipam' for switching between new
and old IPAM implementation.
By default new IPAM is turned off.

DocImpact
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I81806a43ecc6f0a7b293ce3e70d09d1e266b9f02

  ability to do rollback actions on db_base level, because rollback
  action (deallocate for allocate) should be called before database
  rollback happened

and old IPAM implementation.

"}, {'number': 64, 'created': '2015-05-14 14:51:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/411cc163e2d453509758da62153749d0beef665c', 'message': 'Refactor and decompose db_base_plugin_v2.py

Refactoring step before Pluggable IPAM can be applied.
db_base_plugin_v2 is decomposed into several files:
- db_base_plugin_common - contains getters and common
methods used by db_base_plugin and ipam backends.
This class itself do not inlude any IPAM related code.
- ipam_backend_mixin - stores all common code for both backends.
Is inherited from db_base_plugin_common to access getters.
- ipam_non_pluggable_backend - contains code specific for
non pluggable backend. Built-in IPAM implementation was moved
into this file with small changes.
Is inherited from ipam_backend_mixin.
- ipam_pluggable_backend - (not part of this patch) will implement
pluggable IPAM by calling IPAM Driver.
Is inherited from ipam_backend_mixin.

Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I81806a43ecc6f0a7b293ce3e70d09d1e266b9f02

Changed inheritance chain for NeutronDbPluginV2 to allow switching from
non-pluggable to pluggable implementation.
IpamNonPluggableBackend methods are called on it's instance,
instead of previous way where IpamNonPluggableBackend was parent for
NeutronDbPluginV2.
It allows switching ipam implementation in set_ipam_backend
(IpamNonPluggableBackend to IpamPluggableBackend).
All methods that became public in IpamNonPluggableBackend were renamed.

Gateway IP and allocation pools are tracked using SubnetRequests now.
So allocation pool generating/validating was moved before preparing
SubnetRequest.
Allocation pools are passed as list of IPRanges instead of list of
dicts previously.

Refactoring step before Pluggable IPAM can be applied.

Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I81806a43ecc6f0a7b293ce3e70d09d1e266b9f02

commit_message:
Allow IPAM backend switch

Changed inheritance chain for NeutronDbPluginV2 to allow switching from
non-pluggable to pluggable IPAM implementation.
IpamNonPluggableBackend methods are called on it's instance,
instead of previous way where IpamNonPluggableBackend was parent for
NeutronDbPluginV2.
It allows switching IPAM implementation in set_ipam_backend
(IpamNonPluggableBackend to IpamPluggableBackend).
All methods that became public in IpamNonPluggableBackend were renamed.

This is refactoring step before Pluggable IPAM can be applied.

Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I81806a43ecc6f0a7b293ce3e70d09d1e266b9f02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/36/153236/38 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.ipam import base as ipam# Note(pavel_bondar): Next two methods are used during development cycle # and will be removed once complete switch to new IPAM implementation occurs # Shortcut for checking config variable def is_ipam(): return cfg.CONF.use_pluggable_ipam # This wrapper selects appropriate function to call # depending on 'use_pluggable_ipam' config variable # If it is not set original functions gets called, # otherwise alternative implementation for IPAM is called # Let me know if you think it is overkill and it is better to just use # 'if is_ipam(): call_one_meth else: call another_meth' def call_ipam_if_enabled(ipam_func): def wrapper(original_func): def call_func(*args, **kwargs): if is_ipam(): return ipam_func(*args, **kwargs) else: return original_func(*args, **kwargs) return call_func return wrapper # Note(pbondar): End of part to remove after final switch to IPAM def _allocate_ips_ipam(self, context, fixed_ips, mac_address): """Allocate IP addresses according to the configured fixed_ips. New IPAM interface is used for ip allocation. Keeping it interface compatible for now with _allocate_fixed_ips(), since _allocate_fixed_ips and _allocate_ips_ipam is called with the same arguments. """ ips = [] ipam_driver = ipam.IPAMDriver.get_instance(None) for fixed in fixed_ips: if 'ip_address' in fixed: ip_request = ipam.SpecificAddressRequest( fixed['ip_address'], mac_address) ipam_subnet = ipam_driver.get_subnet(fixed['subnet_id']) ip = ipam_subnet.allocate(ip_request) ips.append({'ip_address': ip, 'subnet_id': fixed['subnet_id']}) # Only subnet ID is specified => need to generate IP # from subnet else: ipam_subnet = ipam_driver.get_subnet(fixed['subnet_id']) ip = ipam_subnet.allocate(ipam.AnyAddressRequest()) ips.append({'ip_address': ip, 'subnet_id': fixed['subnet_id']}) return ips # Selects method to call _allocate_fixed_ips() or # _allocate_ips_ipam() depending on is_ipam() result @call_ipam_if_enabled(_allocate_ips_ipam) if is_ipam(): subnets_for_allocation = [] for subnet in subnets: subnets_for_allocation.append({'subnet_id': subnet['id']}) ips = self._allocate_ips_ipam(context, subnets_for_allocation, p['mac_address']) else: # Split into v4 and v6 subnets v4 = [] v6_stateful = [] v6_stateless = [] for subnet in subnets: if subnet['ip_version'] == 4: v4.append(subnet) else: if ipv6_utils.is_auto_address_subnet(subnet): v6_stateless.append(subnet) else: v6_stateful.append(subnet) for subnet in v6_stateless: prefix = subnet['cidr'] ip_address = ipv6_utils.get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64( prefix, p['mac_address']) if not self._check_unique_ip( context, p['network_id'], subnet['id'], ip_address.format()): raise n_exc.IpAddressInUse( net_id=p['network_id'], ip_address=ip_address.format()) ips.append({'ip_address': ip_address.format(), 'subnet_id': subnet['id']}) version_subnets = [v4, v6_stateful] for subnets in version_subnets: if subnets: result = NeutronDbPluginV2._generate_ip(context, subnets) ips.append({'ip_address': result['ip_address'], 'subnet_id': result['subnet_id']}) if not is_ipam(): ip_range = models_v2.IPAvailabilityRange( ipallocationpool=ip_pool, first_ip=pool['start'], last_ip=pool['end']) context.session.add(ip_range) if is_ipam(): # TODO(pavel_bondar): Pass fully prepared SubnetPool ipam_driver = ipam.IPAMDriver.get_instance(None) subnet_request = ipam.SpecificSubnet( net, owner=tenant_id, neutron_id=subnet.id, gateway_ip=s['gateway_ip'], allocation_pools=s['allocation_pools']) # We don't use subnet here, just create ipam_driver.allocate_subnet(subnet_request) if is_ipam(): # Note(pbondar); Call to IPAM should not be performed inside of # transaction, but do not see yet a good way to get cidr # in this method outside db transaction. # Would it be better to pass subnet_id to remove_subnet? ipam_driver = ipam.IPAMDriver.get_instance(None) cidr = netaddr.IPNetwork(subnet['cidr']) ipam_driver.remove_subnet(cidr)
deleted_lines: # Split into v4 and v6 subnets v4 = [] v6_stateful = [] v6_stateless = [] for subnet in subnets: if subnet['ip_version'] == 4: v4.append(subnet) else: if ipv6_utils.is_auto_address_subnet(subnet): v6_stateless.append(subnet) else: v6_stateful.append(subnet) for subnet in v6_stateless: prefix = subnet['cidr'] ip_address = ipv6_utils.get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64( prefix, p['mac_address']) if not self._check_unique_ip( context, p['network_id'], subnet['id'], ip_address.format()): raise n_exc.IpAddressInUse( net_id=p['network_id'], ip_address=ip_address.format()) ips.append({'ip_address': ip_address.format(), 'subnet_id': subnet['id']}) version_subnets = [v4, v6_stateful] for subnets in version_subnets: if subnets: result = NeutronDbPluginV2._generate_ip(context, subnets) ips.append({'ip_address': result['ip_address'], 'subnet_id': result['subnet_id']}) ip_range = models_v2.IPAvailabilityRange( ipallocationpool=ip_pool, first_ip=pool['start'], last_ip=pool['end']) context.session.add(ip_range)

commit_message:
Fix unit tests failing caused by new Mock release

Since the mock 1.1.1 calling of function 'assert_called' and
'assert_called_once' raises the AttributeError.
In current patchset calling of these functions is fixed

Change-Id: I5c21bb3f6cfd8cc095a277ead80794e97bb63c72

subject: Add app in the nodejs mongodb template
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-09 21:25:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator/commit/bd5a074f070af5f3e88fd5418354464e423f1942', 'message': "Add app in the nodejs mongodb template

The current template does not make much sense as it's having nodejs and
mongodb deployed on two different instances but without any connection
between them. Add a nodejs app on the app server which uses mongodb database.
Nodejs custom type is not needed as it can use webserver type. Also, a better
test will be added with mapping to actual HOT template, not just resources, as
 part of generator side work.

Change-Id: I7f4ed72368bf7fcc89da6fbe9b322b8c6872e100
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-09 21:28:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator/commit/cc3ccbd67820e5ad3bb4d74935bb092c7c1b3332', 'message': "Add app in the nodejs mongodb template

The current template does not make much sense as it's having nodejs and
mongodb deployed on two different instances but without any connection
between them. Add a nodejs app on the app server which uses mongodb database.
Nodejs custom type is not needed as it can use webserver type. Also, a better

commit_message:
Add app in the nodejs mongodb template

The current template does not make much sense as it's having nodejs and
mongodb deployed on two different instances but without any connection
between them. Add a nodejs app on the app server which uses mongodb database.
Nodejs custom type is not needed as it can use webserver type. Also, a better
test will be added with mapping to actual HOT template, not just resources, as
part of generator side work.

Partial-Bug: #1452545

Change-Id: I7f4ed72368bf7fcc89da6fbe9b322b8c6872e100
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-translator refs/changes/73/200273/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - custom_types/paypalpizzastore_nodejs_app.yaml default: http://github.com/paypal/rest-api-sample-app-nodejs.git paypal_pizzastore: type: tosca.nodes.WebApplication.PayPalPizzaStore properties: github_url: { get_input: github_url } node: nodejs - database_connection: node: mongo_db interfaces: Standard: configure: implementation: nodejs/config.sh inputs: github_url: http://github.com/paypal/rest-api-sample-app-nodejs.git mongodb_ip: { get_attribute: [mongo_server, private_address] } start: nodejs/start.sh nodejs: type: tosca.nodes.WebServer requirements: - host: mongo_db: type: tosca.nodes.Database requirements: - host: node: mongo_dbms interfaces: Standard: create: mongodb/create_database.sh - host:
deleted_lines: - custom_types/nodejs.yaml default: https://github.com/sample.git nodejs: type: tosca.nodes.SoftwareComponent.Nodejs properties: github_url: https://github.com/sample.git capability: tosca.capabilities.Container relationship: tosca.relationships.HostedOn configure: implementation: nodejs/config.sh inputs: github_url: { get_property: [ SELF, github_url ] } mongodb_ip: { get_attribute: [mongo_server, private_address] } start: nodejs/start.sh - host: capability: tosca.capabilities.Container relationship: tosca.relationships.HostedOn properties: port: 27017

subject: freezer scheduler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-14 22:22:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/freezer/commit/6516567c84b47077ff7a264ebb708891cdcf8921', 'message': 'WIP freezer scheduler

The freezer scheduler is to be executed
as daemon process on the client machines

It has the following responsibilities:

  * when using the api:
    - register -if necessary- as a client in the api
    - download the list of jobs from the api
    - save the configuration of jobs on local disk
    - schedule the jobs for execution
    - launch the freezer client at the scheduled time
    - collect metadata and exit codes and upload them to the api
    - periodically poll the api for new/updated jobs

  * when not using the api
    - load jobs configurations from files
    - schedule the jobs for execution
    - launch the freezer client at the scheduled time

The freezer scheduler can also be used to upload/download
configuration files using the following positional parameters:

  config-upload
  config-download

or to register the client in the api using the positional parameter:

  client-register

Implements blueprint: freezer-scheduler-start

Change-Id: I06ae202a0f464f7240c137744a5b54d1177cabd9
